title: Vice President of Business Development, Media & Technology
description: • Identifies trendsetter ideas by researching industry and related events, publications, and announcements; tracking individual contributors and their accomplishments. • Locates or proposes potential business deals by contacting potential partners; discovering and exploring opportunities. • Screens potential business deals by analyzing market strategies, deal requirements, potential, and financials; evaluating options; resolving internal priorities; recommending equity investments. • Develops negotiating strategies and positions by studying integration of new venture with company strategies and operations; examining risks and potentials; estimating partners' needs and goals. • Closes new business deals by coordinating requirements; developing and negotiating contracts; integrating contract requirements with business operations. • Protects organization's value by keeping information confidential. • Maintaining personal networks; participating in professional organizations. • Enhances organization reputation by exploring opportunities to add value. • Builds market position by locating, developing, defining, negotiating, and closing business relationships. • Provide subject matter expertise on analytic methodologies and counterintelligence leading to increased collaboration in the virtual community of Intelligence professionals • Moderate and provide original content for Bi-weekly Blog on topics of interest to IC Agency professionals • Copy editing and proofing for ongoing mass publication special interest projects • Liaison between The Intelligence Community LLC and Public Affairs offices of all IC Agencies, leading to increased exposure and discourse on pertinent IC issues • Schedules and Conducts interviews with senior IC leaders for inclusion on The Intelligence Community, LLC You Tube Channel • Cultivates relational/professional bridges between IC agencies and private sector companies, resulting in increased cooperation and effectiveness

summary: One of the best part of my career is managing and directing operations and strategic planning for intelligence collection. Using THE SOURCE SYSTEM (TSS), an open-source intelligence, surveillance and tracking system I designed for The Intelligence Community, LLC., we launched the first of many TSS intelligence products - The Source WORLDBEAT premium newsletters in December 2014. I also designed and implemented a predictive analytic system called The Redwine Model (TRM). TRM is a hybrid Geographic Intelligence System designed to provide intelligence information for a search for missing children. TRM produces ranked outputs based on a multitude of calculated inputs from crowd-sourcing open-source intelligence, counterintelligence, intelligence analysis, intelligence operations, and threat assessments. The child's remains were located in the third of 50 ranked locations in June 2013. Since then the system has been utilized to investigate his murder and compile data for court proceedings. This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

summary: One of the best part of my career is managing and directing operations and strategic planning for intelligence collection. Using THE SOURCE SYSTEM (TSS), an open-source intelligence, surveillance and tracking system I designed for The Intelligence Community, LLC., we launched the first of many TSS intelligence products - The Source WORLDBEAT premium newsletters in December 2014. I also designed and implemented a predictive analytic system called The Redwine Model (TRM). TRM is a hybrid Geographic Intelligence System designed to provide intelligence information for a search for missing children. TRM produces ranked outputs based on a multitude of calculated inputs from crowd-sourcing open-source intelligence, counterintelligence, intelligence analysis, intelligence operations, and threat assessments. The child's remains were located in the third of 50 ranked locations in June 2013. Since then the system has been utilized to investigate his murder and compile data for court proceedings. This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

title: Vice President - Intelligence Solutions
description: • Development of Strategic and Tactical Competitive Intelligence Solutions in support of Event Legacy Development, Operations, and Revenue Generation. • Cultivation and management of Business Intelligence Unit designed to provide targeted and intelligent sales, marketing, and management for golf industry ventures • Directs and manages multi-faceted social media marketing program • Act as liaison between Event Director and the golf course to find the best value for event • Act as contract negotiators • Provide a clear, easy-to-use website for tournament registration • Send e-blasts reminding participants of the event • Be available 24-7 for to answer questions! • Train volunteers on golf etiquette and their day-of duties • Coordinate advertising • Be present at the tournament to help with day-of registration and sales • Coordinate on and off course games and activities (Putting contests, hole-in-one contests, silent auctions, etc.) • Provide high-quality merchandise for participants • Help client raise as much money as possible for event

summary: One of the best part of my career is managing and directing operations and strategic planning for intelligence collection. Using THE SOURCE SYSTEM (TSS), an open-source intelligence, surveillance and tracking system I designed for The Intelligence Community, LLC., we launched the first of many TSS intelligence products - The Source WORLDBEAT premium newsletters in December 2014. I also designed and implemented a predictive analytic system called The Redwine Model (TRM). TRM is a hybrid Geographic Intelligence System designed to provide intelligence information for a search for missing children. TRM produces ranked outputs based on a multitude of calculated inputs from crowd-sourcing open-source intelligence, counterintelligence, intelligence analysis, intelligence operations, and threat assessments. The child's remains were located in the third of 50 ranked locations in June 2013. Since then the system has been utilized to investigate his murder and compile data for court proceedings. This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

summary: One of the best part of my career is managing and directing operations and strategic planning for intelligence collection. Using THE SOURCE SYSTEM (TSS), an open-source intelligence, surveillance and tracking system I designed for The Intelligence Community, LLC., we launched the first of many TSS intelligence products - The Source WORLDBEAT premium newsletters in December 2014. I also designed and implemented a predictive analytic system called The Redwine Model (TRM). TRM is a hybrid Geographic Intelligence System designed to provide intelligence information for a search for missing children. TRM produces ranked outputs based on a multitude of calculated inputs from crowd-sourcing open-source intelligence, counterintelligence, intelligence analysis, intelligence operations, and threat assessments. The child's remains were located in the third of 50 ranked locations in June 2013. Since then the system has been utilized to investigate his murder and compile data for court proceedings. This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

summary: One of the best part of my career is managing and directing operations and strategic planning for intelligence collection. Using THE SOURCE SYSTEM (TSS), an open-source intelligence, surveillance and tracking system I designed for The Intelligence Community, LLC., we launched the first of many TSS intelligence products - The Source WORLDBEAT premium newsletters in December 2014. I also designed and implemented a predictive analytic system called The Redwine Model (TRM). TRM is a hybrid Geographic Intelligence System designed to provide intelligence information for a search for missing children. TRM produces ranked outputs based on a multitude of calculated inputs from crowd-sourcing open-source intelligence, counterintelligence, intelligence analysis, intelligence operations, and threat assessments. The child's remains were located in the third of 50 ranked locations in June 2013. Since then the system has been utilized to investigate his murder and compile data for court proceedings. This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

This system is capable of delivering predictive outputs to speed up successful recovery of other missing children. OSINTAnalyst.com provides an intelligence support node to TRM that facilitates future predictive models and innovative intelligence solutions. I was called to intelligence work while working as an on-air radio news reporter at KPFT 90.1 FM in Houston, TX in October of 2002. This is important because it allowed me a unique opportunity to meet and interview President George W. Bush, former SECDEF Robert Gates—he was still president of Texas A&M University at the time—and Senator John Cornyn. These individuals imparted lasting impressions on me, but what Mr. Gates said towards the end of our interview sticks with me to this day. Gates spoke of the Iraq war saying “we needed a Churchill, but there were none to be found,” displaying a distinct willingness to engage in deeper thinking on issues that would bring lasting change to the US Intelligence Community (USIC).

title: Senior Information Systems Engineer
description: Work with and prototype systems using the latest open source and commercial technologies (e.g., Hadoop, Solr, and Accumulo). Responsibilities include working with customers to understand their data and to identify the best technology and approach to achieve their goals. Generally, this also involves prototyping the initial system and demonstrating its capabilities to both technical developers and a much less technical user base. I was also an instructor for the corporate hands-on analytic cloud computing course that covered topics such as Hadoop and Accumulo. The hands-on portion of the class demonstrates how to interact with Hadoop and Accumulo via their Java APIs.

title: Sr Recruiting Specialist, Intelligence Services
description: • Perform full cycle recruiting for a defense contractor, Mission Essential, in support of all intelligence contracts. This requires cold calling, prospecting, networking, negotiating salaries, and processing candidates. • Support multiple DoD customers on various contracts both in the United States and multiple OCONUS locations including Europe and Afghanistan. • Recruit for several different types of professionals including but not limited to: Intelligence/All Source Analysts, CI/HUMINT Specialists, HUMINT Analysts and Collectors, SIGINT Specialists, Targeting Specialists, Knowledge Management Advisors, SIGINT/Geolocation Operators, Linguists/Interpreters • Responsible for providing key personnel for all business development proposals to bring in new work for the company • Review Statement of Work (SOW) for each contract and define requirements for personnel on each contract • Recruit personnel to fill proposal requirements for acquisition of new contract business and supported the following Business Development Wins:   OMNIBUS - $1.2 billion intelligence prime contract, ISSA - $475 million intelligence prime contract. Ft Gordon Contract - $750 million intelligence prime contract, JAC Molesworth Task Order - $80 million intelligence prime contract; Habeas Corpus Task Order - $51.4 million prime contract.    Key Accomplishments:   • Achieved 95% fill rate on contract which meets highest fill rate standard set by the government • Recruiter of the Quarter (Department wide): 4th Quarter 2012 and 1st Quarter 2013  • Recruiter of the Month (Department wide): Feb 2010, August 2010, Jan 2011, Jan 2012, Sept 2012  • Nominated for Employee of the Month (Company wide): Jan 2012

title: Account Manager/Recruiter
description: • Main Responsibilities include supporting sales team by growing all aspects of the account through building relationships with clients and further introducing our services to different departments. • Act as liaison for human resources department and assist them with integral goals such as reducing turnover and providing them with insight to market trends • Duties include coaching associates, conducting associate reviews, and terminations • Responsible for all new hire orientations which includes explanation of benefits, new hire paperwork, and separation paperwork • Recruit for a broad spectrum of companies ranging form small privately owned firms to fortune 500 companies on a contract to hire basis • Conduct all aspect of recruiting process including but not limited to candidate generation, resume screening, candidate scheduling, interviewing, testing, coaching, negotiating offers, and finalizing new hires • Balance the needs of our client with the needs of the candidate • Ability to prioritize multiple tasks while working under strict deadlines in fast pace environment

title: Co-Founder and Chief Operating Officer
description: ▪ Led strategy, business development and proposal management support for both government and commercial efforts, yielding multi-million dollar wins ▪ Performed market penetration to identify and qualify business opportunities. Developed and maintained both government and commercial pipelines ▪ Designed and created investor pitch decks that led to two successful capital raises of $5 million ▪ Re-imagined company’s branding strategy and created new website to introduce Novitas to the world and creating all presentations, capabilities briefs, and promotional videos ▪ Provided strategic direction and design/UI/UX input for technology product, as well as competitive intelligence and research to guide launch into commercial market ▪ Led company audit team for DCAA audit, resulting in an “approved” accounting system. Interacted daily with company accountants to ensure up-to-date and accurate company financials ▪ Developed invoicing system and managed third-party vendors and consultants for proper billing and payment ▪ Responsible for contracts management, including funding levels and ceiling, spending, modifications, contracts reporting and tracking for DCAA, etc. ▪ Acted as Facility Security Officer for company’s TOP SECRET facility clearance ▪ Responsible for full-cycle proposal development, led strategic corporate pursuits with government and commercial customers ▪ Implemented best practices for proposal management activities, including: solutions discussions, win theme development, formal color team reviews, story-boarding, volume development, compliance checks, desktop publishing (DTP), graphics, printing, production, packaging, and delivery ▪ Created and implemented an employee handbook, complete with all company policies, and conducted required training ▪ Administered company benefits program – 401k, medical, dental, vision, short-term and long-term disability, and ADD.

title: Business Development Manager - Director of Program Development
description: ▪ Led all business development efforts for the company and designed and codified sales pipelines transitioning the company from managing opportunities on spreadsheets to using Salesforce.com so all stakeholders could see and participate in strategic bids ▪ Positioned TBG as a prime contractor for strategic opportunities by cultivating long-term relationships with industry partners and government customers – constructing and leading strong, competitive teams to success and negotiating favorable work-share agreements ▪ Won new work with a new customer valued at $23.8B (US Army EAGLE II) and was responsible for all of the business development, capture, and proposal management for this effort, including management of more than 50 teammates ▪ Won a $32M contract (LOGCAP IV) that expanded our core competencies into a new market (logistics) ▪ Conducted market penetration to identify and qualify business opportunities, including collection of competitive intelligence, performing SWOT assessments, conducting gap analyses, and identifying our discriminators to determine viability of p-win. Briefed senior leadership on new business opportunities and growth markets ▪ Responsible for the full-cycle of bid and proposal response, to include: opportunity shaping, White Papers, responding to Sources Sought, RFIs/RFQs, full RFP responses, and BAFOs and management of proposal team in a deadline-driven environment. This included proposal development, desktop publishing (DTP), graphics, production, packaging, and delivery ▪ Attended, exhibited, and participated in trade shows, conferences, industry days, and networking events ▪ Developed new marketing materials to support growth strategy and promote TBG offerings to potential customers and industry partners

description: ▪ Reporting to the Chief of Staff, I was selected to lead the execution of the company’s corporate strategic management system through an implementation of the Balanced Scorecard and an enterprise risk management program that drove the performance of over 8,000 people across 10 countries ▪ Translated corporate objectives and associated performance metrics, and defined, assigned, monitored, and measured the initiatives and projects to support those objectives for alignment with corporate strategy and mission ▪ Collaborated across departments and business units to capture existing business model (i.e. structure, processes, systems, human capital, budgeting, and resource allocation) to inform corporate strategic management process ▪ Provided cross-departmental functional support and coordination for proposals totaling $10B in revenue

summary: WINNING REVENUE THROUGH STRATEGY AND NARRATIVE Solution-focused leader with 10 years’ experience helping organizations win. Capitalizes on background in proposal management, business development, capture, strategy, and operations to transform competitive intelligence into business growth. Cross-functional manager who cultivates collaboration and alignment, interfacing effortlessly with all levels of the organization, external customers, teammates and stakeholders. Recognized ability to develop targeted solutions, in increasingly competitive environments, to win. Leverages both start-up and large company experience to manage complex organizational challenges and contribute to their successful solutions. Fosters strategic partnerships to maximize opportunity and facilitate growth. Adaptive, creative executive who thrives in fluid environments and seeks out opportunities to lead, serve, and develop herself and others by creating meaningful relationships across the organization.

title: OCONUS Program Site Manager, Bahrain and Qatar
description: ▪ Ran a multi-national intelligence program with a multi-national workforce in the CENTCOM area of responsibility (AOR) supporting COMUSNAVCENT Navy and Coalition Forces Counter-Intelligence (CI) maritime operations. ▪ Managed more than 53 CATI/CATII/CATIII linguists (speaking Arabic, Persian Farsi, Pashto, Hindi, Tamil, Urdu, Baluchi, and Somali) stationed throughout Qatar, Bahrain, and Djibouti. This workforce included U.S citizens with Top Secret and Secret clearances, as well as un-cleared local national personnel ▪ Responsible for operational site management, mission scheduling, resource allocation, budget forecasting and management, project management, attrition/retention, operating expense reporting, and 100% accountability of personnel and property ▪ Managed dozens of simultaneous, high-priority, quick-turn requests for linguist assets from the customer(s) at any given time ▪ Established all operations to support a brand new mission in Qatar including setting-up required business infrastructure (obtain sponsor, licenses, visas, logistics, local leases, etc.), developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and employee handbook for mission performance and daily operations supporting COMUSNAVCENT customer, created marketing materials to augment recruiting efforts to staff this program, established new-hire training on-ramping and training program (to include host nation compliance, deployment familiarization, mission training, etc.)

title: Proposal Manager
description: ▪ Experienced proposal management professional with proven ability to manage proposal efforts through every phase of the business development lifecycle ▪ Led effort to win $25M program supporting U.S. Army INSCOM CI/HUMINT and Intel Analyst Program (Native Language Research Analysts) ▪ Established policies, practices and procedures to manage the proposal development process (proposal outlines, compliance matrices, proposal management plans, proposal development worksheets, storyboards, budgets, and production schedules) that led to an increase of revenue in excess of $190.8M in 12 months. ▪ Managed both small and large proposal teams and experienced in coordinating with other departments (BD, Operations, Finance, Contracts, Compliance, Recruiting, etc.), as well as external teammates, to ensure section completion, incorporation of win themes/hot buttons/discriminators, use of appropriate graphics, single voice, and formatting. ▪ Responsible for creation, management, and oversight of a comprehensive bid plan throughout life of the win process (customer analysis, competitive analysis, capture strategy, win strategy, and teaming) ▪ Negotiated and coordinated teaming, work-share, and non-disclosure agreements to competitively position to win contracts ▪ Identified, recruited and vetted key management personnel for proposal submission and follow-on operational support ▪ Responsible for full-cycle proposal development, including desktop publishing (DTP), graphics, production, packaging, and delivery

title: Arabic Linguist/Translator
description: ▪ Trained in Modern Standard Arabic at the Defense Language Institute in Monterey, CA ▪ Assigned to mission requiring Iraqi Dialect, acquired dialect proficiency in 3 months ▪ Translated and analyzed real-time intelligence and sensitive information, collecting HUMINT / CI materials to disseminate vital intelligence reports to customers supporting missions worldwide ▪ Disseminated critical information through intelligence reports, assessments, and briefings in a fast-paced, high-pressure environment focused on protecting US and coalition assets through translation and analysis of time-sensitive intelligence ▪ Translated and analyzed Arabic signals data and intelligence (SIGINT) involving both voice and written tasks ▪ Scanned materials (voice and written) to identify items that require further processing ▪ Provide Essential Elements of Information (EEIs), gists, summary and verbatim transcripts, and translations of material ▪ Performed SIGINT functions including assembling, exploiting, analyzing, and delivering intelligence information and reports to decision-makers ▪ Skilled in SIGINT data processing systems and Distributed Common Ground Systems (DCGS) supporting intelligence, surveillances, and reconnaissance (ISR) collection and analysis

title: Adviser / Subject Matter Expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) Programs
company: Defense Language and National Security Education Office
description: + Advises the Defense Language and National Security Education Office (DLNSEO) within the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness + Provides subject matter expertise on culture training policy development including Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs + Develops and tests Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) training material in partnership with the Joint Staff and Joint Knowledge Online (JKO) + Coordinates with the Defense Language and National Security Education Office (DLNSEO), Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) organizations to evaluate Cross Cultural Competency (3C), cultural readiness, and region specific education and training capabilities + Coordinates meetings with language and culture course coordinators at Defense Language and National Security Education Office (DLNSEO) funded Language Training Centers (LTCs). + Advises Defense Language and National Security Education Office and senior Department of Defense policy makers on the proper integration of Language, Regional Expertise and Culture capabilities to ensure regional preparedness for Department of Defense global missions + Assists Defense Language and National Security Education Office in developing a coherent, holistic plan to provide cultural readiness including general, regional and group specific education and training. + Content Manager and Social Media Manager for www.CultureReady.org which leads the public discussion on what it takes to make the Department of Defense and supporting organizations #cultureReady (follow on Twitter: @DLNSEO_culture) Keywords: Under Secretary of Defense, Cross Cultural Competency, Policy Development, Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) Programs, Training, Partnerships, Joint Knowledge Online (JKO), Planning, Social Media Management

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

title: President / CEO
description: + Launched www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com in 2012 as an exclusive online community of national security and intelligence professionals - the site will become a peer-to-peer marketplace for national security freelance work starting in March 2015 + Manages the largest professional network for national security and intelligence professionals on LinkedIn, "The Intelligence Community", now with over 49k members + Consults on disruptive technology proposals and leveraging emerging media tools for business development and capture in the defense space + Consults on innovative implementation of emerging technology for diplomacy and intelligence in the Intelligence Community, Defense and Security sectors + Provides services to small business owners and job seekers in national security Keywords: 1099, freelance, consulting, National Security, policy, strategic communications, diplomacy, intelligence, LinkedIn, social media, business development, innovation, disruption, consulting, proposal writing, capture, collaboration, small business, job seeker, events, technology, media, civil society, Internet freedom, information security, democracy, human rights, governance

title: Editor in Chief, Foreign Area Officer Association Journal of International Affairs
description: + Coordinates with Editorial Board for the quarterly production of the peer reviewed journal "International Affairs" for the Foreign Area Officer Association (FAOA). + FAOA is a 501c3, nonprofit professional group bringing together thought leadership in the fields of intelligence, security cooperation, foreign military sales, stability operations, peacekeeping, diplomacy and geopolitical advisory expertise for the US Department of Defense, US government stakeholders and allied governments. + Find out more about FAOA at www.FAOA.org Keywords: Editing, writing, editorial board, peer reviewed, journal, international affairs, Foreign Area Officer, non-profit, nonprofit, associations, 501c3, intelligence, security cooperation, foreign military sales, stability operations, peacekeeping, diplomacy, geopolitical, advising, DOD, Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Air Force, OSD, DIA, DSCA, ODNI

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

title: LCDR
description: + Commander, Naval Forces Europe and Africa – Commander, Sixth Fleet (CNE/A-C6F) Maritime Partnership Program (NR CNE/A-C6F MPP Det 413) + Originated in the CNO’s 2005 initiative for a Global Maritime Partnership. + Seeks to develop a maritime strategy with nations throughout the world, working together to establish maritime safety and security cooperation. In South America the program is called the Southern Partnership Station, and in the Pacific, the Pacific Partnership Station. + Commander, Sixth Fleet reports directly to Commander, Naval Forces Europe/Africa and is a source provider for operations in the EUCOM and AFRICOM Theater. + Assigned to Commander, Sixth Fleet are five reserve MPP units that provide this maritime partnership support. One unit is assigned to the Black and Caspian Sea region and one is a Sixth Fleet Headquarters unit. The other three MPP units are divided geographically on the African continent + MPP 413 supports West and Central Africa Gulf of Guinea region + MPP 413 supports the Africa Partnership Station (APS), which is a collaborative strategy with U.S., European and African nations designed to help coastal nations in Africa improve maritime safety and security + APS can be thought of as a floating Mobile Training Team (MTT) consisting of non-governmental organizations and military services from the U.S., Europe and Africa. + MPP 413 supports these APS visits by deploying prior to the ship’s arrival and coordinating ship logistics, training events, military officer calls, humanitarian assistance (medical/dental/veterinary) and social events. + MPP 413 presence contributes to CNE/A-C6F by developing and sustaining relationships with maritime forces of designated countries, establishing and strengthening partnerships as part of the overall Theater Security Cooperation (TSC) strategy + MPP DET 413 is also responsible for maintaining subject matter expertise on the AOR Keywords: Maritime partnerships, Africa, AFRICOM, CNE, EUCOM

title: Senior Consultant

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

summary: Adviser at the Defense Language and National Security Education Office as an expert in Language, Regional Expertise and Culture (LREC) programs (on contract). Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

Also serve as CEO of The Intelligence Community LLC moderating the largest LinkedIn group for National Security professionals (http://goo.gl/fPo45) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com, a peer-to-peer marketplace for freelance work in national security Honors + Personally requested by DIA Director to be Aide de Camp + Board Member for the FAO Association, the Cold War Museum and on the Editorial Board for the Journal of Mediterranean and Balkan Intelligence + Editor in Chief for the Foreign Area Officer Association Journal, "International Affairs" + Selected in Young Professionals in Foreign Policy “Top 99 Leaders under 33” + Delphi Fellow, BigThink.com + Malone Fellow in Middle Eastern Studies Books: + "In the Shadow of Greatness" Tom Brokaw calls it a "must read for all Americans" | 2x LA Times Bestseller - http://usna2002.org/shadowofgreatness + "Hacking the Job Search" - http://goo.gl/M0voM3 Articles: + “Using Social Media to Network and Curate Information” FAO Journal, Feb 2011 + "Digital Diplomacy" FAO Journal, May 2013 Lectures: + "Putting Community Back in the Intelligence Community" GOVSEC, May 2014 + "Implications of the De Facto Intelligence Community" Panasonic Federal Security Symposium, Sep 2013 + "Beyond Intelligence: Wisdom in the Information Age" GOV 2.0 LA 2013 + “The Arab Spring and Social Media” US Naval Academy Center for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, Oct 2011 + “The Persian Blogging Phenomenon” US Naval Academy, Jan 2009 Keywords: Interagency, Intelligence Analysis, Intelligence Support, Doctrine, Military Intelligence, Intelligence Products, Civilians, Intelligence Operations, Security Policy, National Security Issues

title: Senior Advisor, Research & Compliance
description: Advise pharmaceutical and biotech companies on legal and regulatory compliance. Extensive familiarity with the FDA approval process, FDA oversight of advertising and promotion, Federal and State False Claims Acts, Federal Anti-Kickback Statute, the Food, Drug & Cosmetic Act (FDCA), Data Privacy (HIPAA, HITECH, and others), Food & Drug Administration Amendment Act of 2007 (FDAAA), Prescription Drug Marketing Act of 1987 (PDMA), PhRMA Code and AdvaMed Code, the federal Sunshine Law, Drug Quality & Security Act (DQSA), OIG compliance guidance, regulation and oversight of in vitro diagnostic (IVD) devices, genetic tests, and laboratory developed tests (LDTs), federal and state marketing and disclosure laws,state licensing laws for wholesalers/manufacturers, prescriptive authority for health care professionals, state record retention, controlled substance licensing, state theft/loss reporting requirements for legend/controlled/samples, and state physician dispensing laws.

summary: Currently, I work for a health and life-science service company, which provides compliance management services, computer validation, project management, audits & assessments, training and regulatory support services to pharmaceutical and biotech companies. My primary role involves researching and analyzing state and federal laws and advising companies on how to stay in compliance with those laws. I also serve as an Analyst and Internship Program Manager with The Intelligence Community, LLC, which operates the largest LinkedIn group for Intelligence and National Security professionals (with over 37k members) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com. Apply to join the LinkedIn group → http://goo.gl/fPo45. Publications: ★"Extremists in the Ranks," in The Syria Policy Playbook, Policy Playbook Series 1. The Intelligence Community, LLC (2013). ★"The Muslim Brotherhood: Responding to Competing Ideologies that Endure," in The Egypt Policy Playbook, Policy Playbook Series 2. The Intelligence Community, LLC (2014).

summary: Currently, I work for a health and life-science service company, which provides compliance management services, computer validation, project management, audits & assessments, training and regulatory support services to pharmaceutical and biotech companies. My primary role involves researching and analyzing state and federal laws and advising companies on how to stay in compliance with those laws. I also serve as an Analyst and Internship Program Manager with The Intelligence Community, LLC, which operates the largest LinkedIn group for Intelligence and National Security professionals (with over 37k members) as well as www.TheIntelligenceCommunity.com. Apply to join the LinkedIn group → http://goo.gl/fPo45. Publications: ★"Extremists in the Ranks," in The Syria Policy Playbook, Policy Playbook Series 1. The Intelligence Community, LLC (2013). ★"The Muslim Brotherhood: Responding to Competing Ideologies that Endure," in The Egypt Policy Playbook, Policy Playbook Series 2. The Intelligence Community, LLC (2014).

description: Conduct Research; Collect, organize, and analyze data on current events in Middle East and North Africa (MENA), supporting collaboration among intelligence professionals. education: [{"name"=>"Dickinson College", "description"=>"", "period"=>"1966 – 1970"}, {"name"=>"George Washington University Graduate School of International Relations", "description"=>"None, International Relations and Affairs", "period"=>"1970 – 1973"}]
summary: From 1970-2006, I worked as an operations officer/Senior Intelligence Service officer for the National Clandestine Service (formerly, the Directorate of Operations) of the CIA, abroad and in Washington, running and managing clandestine agent and technical collection operations. From 2006-2011, after I retired as a staff officer, I worked as an Independent Contractor for the Agency, primarily as a navigator/senior instructor/mentor for our new, incoming Clandestine Service Officers, a great way to pay the Agency back for a very meaningful and rewarding career. Since my "final" retirement in 2011, as a member of the Fairfax County Democratic Committee, I have participated as a volunteer in political campaigns, primarily helping the Obama for America campaign and other Democratic candidates. I also do some volunteer work at my Temple, take courses at the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute (affiliated with George Mason University), attend Smithsonian seminars and Folger Shakespeare Library performances, travel, engage in physical fitness activities, and watch and occasionally attend Washington Nationals and Washington Capitals games. I also remain an unofficial "advisor"/mentor for junior and even senior colleagues still serving in the National Clandestine Service.

title: Operations Officer
description: I served as an operations officer/Senior Intelligence Service officer (and Component leader) overseas and in the Washington area for the National Clandestine Service of the CIA, running and managing clandestine agent and technical collection operations. Following my retirement after 35 plus years as a staff officer for the Agency, I worked until April 2011 as an Independent Contractor for the Agency, primarily as a navigator/senior teacher/mentor for our new, incoming Clandestine Service officers. I also worked for the Recruitment Center and, in my final year as a contractor, as a Special Advisor to the Chief of one of our key operational Divisions.

title: Solutions Engineer
description: As an SE with Hortonworks, my job is to help your company harness the power and superior business intelligence that can be gained with implementing Big Data into your IT infrastructure using the open source product Hadoop. We can provide you with an Enterprise class distribution of an Hadoop stack and provide you with the training, consulting, and support to implement it into your current IT infrastructure. I am currently focused on supporting the Federal sector of our business and specifically the members of the Intelligence Community (IC). I am here to answer your questions about Hadoop and help you determine the appropriate use-cases for your agency so that you can enhance your current support level to your missions. I can also help you wade through the extensive Hadoop eco-system to find the right analytic product(s) to layer on top of our stack to help you uncover new findings in your various data sets and present it in an easily digestible format. Email me at fromano@Hortonworks.com to help you leverage the power of Big Data!

title: Consulting Software Engineer
description: Performed full life-cycle development of test automation software using C, C++ and Visual Basic. Used the Intel Pre-boot Execution Environment (PXE) to develop initial software load under manufacturing automation for storage processors. Assisted in development and deployment of test plans, procedures and schedules for Fibre Channel storage product. Provided review of test requirements and test plans to ensure completeness and correctness of test program. Facilitated cross-functional communication between design engineering and manufacturing.

title: Software Architect
description: Responsible for design and development of the next generation uniform test management tool to be utilized in all manufacturing test stations excluding ICT. Key design goals included Unit Under Test (UUT) abstraction, multiple UUT support, data collection, library development for adjunctive test equipment (Electronic Loads, Power Supplies, SmartBits, Qualmark HASS chamber, etc.) control and development of user friendly go/no-go type GUI.

education: [{"name"=>"DeVry University", "description"=>"BS, Information Systems", "period"=>"2006 – 2008"}]
summary: I have over 20 years of experience in the technology space. I spent some early days in virtual reality, 3D modeling and AutoCAD. I made a shift towards networking in the late 90's and then jumped into software engineering. I wrote my first commercial application in PowerBuilder (glad those days are over) and graduated to Java. I was fortunate to work for a small company, so I owned the databases, version control, bug tracking, network, app servers, and the like. I have always focused on keeping things simple, scalable, and performant. I made the leap a few years ago to Solution Architecture in the NoSQL space and found it to be exciting helping businesses solve complex big data problems. Now I am working with Hadoop and found that the paradigm of this new big data platform to be game changing.

summary: I have over 20 years of experience in the technology space. I spent some early days in virtual reality, 3D modeling and AutoCAD. I made a shift towards networking in the late 90's and then jumped into software engineering. I wrote my first commercial application in PowerBuilder (glad those days are over) and graduated to Java. I was fortunate to work for a small company, so I owned the databases, version control, bug tracking, network, app servers, and the like. I have always focused on keeping things simple, scalable, and performant. I made the leap a few years ago to Solution Architecture in the NoSQL space and found it to be exciting helping businesses solve complex big data problems. Now I am working with Hadoop and found that the paradigm of this new big data platform to be game changing.

education: [{"name"=>"DeVry University", "description"=>"BS, Information Systems", "period"=>"2006 – 2008"}]
summary: I have over 20 years of experience in the technology space. I spent some early days in virtual reality, 3D modeling and AutoCAD. I made a shift towards networking in the late 90's and then jumped into software engineering. I wrote my first commercial application in PowerBuilder (glad those days are over) and graduated to Java. I was fortunate to work for a small company, so I owned the databases, version control, bug tracking, network, app servers, and the like. I have always focused on keeping things simple, scalable, and performant. I made the leap a few years ago to Solution Architecture in the NoSQL space and found it to be exciting helping businesses solve complex big data problems. Now I am working with Hadoop and found that the paradigm of this new big data platform to be game changing.

title: Consultant - Internal Firm Initiative
description: - Developed multiple Proof of Concepts to apply Big Data/Hadoop to the Financial Services Industry - Developed a prototype solution to offload transaction data from traditional relational databases to cost-efficient Hive/HBase databases. This data was then synthesized with third party data to detect discriminatory lending behavior, identify product recommendations, and create a mortgage refinancing targeting model - In support of above prototype, ingested various forms of structured and unstructured data using Sqoop, Flume and HDFS command line; Transformed and cleansed data using Hive, Pig, JAQL and MapReduce - Helped stand up two Hadoop environments, both using IBM’s Hadoop Distribution – BigInsights, one four node cluster and one six node cluster

title: Consultant - Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)
description: - Worked through the full System Development Lifecycle to implement a compliance monitoring solution that aggregates and analyzes commercial loans (e.g., mortgage, payday, and auto loans) and accounts (e.g., savings account) in support of CFPB’s Supervision, Enforcement, and Fair Lending mission - Transformed business requirements to technical requirements - Led the data integration workstream, ingesting data from multiple external upstream systems and exporting data to downstream systems - Created reports to identify loans of interest for more detailed review by CFPB examiners - Co-led the security workstream to ensure the solution was Center for Internet Security (CIS) compliant

title: Summer Scholar (Intern)
description: Worked on a project to implement a new database for the U.S. Marine Corps (USMC) to support programming, planning and budgeting functions. Prepared cost-benefit analysis to select defect testing software for the new database. Also supported testing including running test scripts, logging results, and tracking errors. Assisted on an employee development strategy project for the USMC which included programming, planning and budgeting personnel. Cataloged internal and external training courses available to employees by competency and level. Worked with fellow interns on a case study involving a complex problem faced by one of Deloitte’s clients. Presented analysis and recommendations to a group of Deloitte partners, principals, and directors.

title: Education & Evaluation Coordinator / Assoc. Director, Section of Education, Evaluation & Research
company: New York Medical College, Department of Surgery
name: Kevin Wolfe
education: [{"name"=>"Hofstra University", "description"=>"", "period"=>"2004 – 2008"}, {"name"=>"Hofstra University", "description"=>"", "period"=>"2002 – 2004"}]
summary: I am an applied psychologist working in graduate surgical education, as what is commonly referred to as a surgical educator. In the Department of Surgery, I serve as an internal consultant for training and development, performance assessment, and program evaluation, as these areas relate to the General Surgery Residency and various Surgical Fellowship Programs. Additionally, I participate in research investigating a variety of educational, clinical and quality improvement topics. Currently, I am actively involved in research relating to the accuracy of performance ratings; the relationship between ratings of behaviors and organizational outcomes; and the use of advanced statistical techniques (e.g. factor analysis) for investigating the construct validity and measurement equivalence of performance ratings. I also have research interests in examining the use of simulation for training and assessment of individual surgeons, as well as surgical teams.

title: Drilling Fluids Engineer
skills: ["Drilling", "Drilling Fluids", "Fluids", "Completion", "Onshore", "Offshore Operations", "Rig", "Offshore", "Waste Management", "Petroleum"]
name: Stefan Surujbally
education: [{"name"=>"University of Trinidad and Tobago", "description"=>"Bachelor of Science (B.Sc.), Process & Utilities Engineering (Chemical)", "period"=>"2006 – 2010"}, {"name"=>"Presentation College San-Fernando", "description"=>"", "period"=>"1999 – 2006"}]
summary: Employed as a Drilling Fluids Engineer for four(4) years. I have worked on both onshore & offshore operations (jack-up, semi-subs type rigs). Most of the wells that I have worked on have involved the use of Oil/Synthetic Based Muds. Also experienced in Inhibitive Water Based Muds and Reservoir Drill-In Fluids (DIF -FAZE-PRO).Experienced with Drilling Waste Management (DWM) Operations (including Verti-G Dryers, Augers, Roto-Hoppers, Vacuums etc). I am also experienced with Well-Bore Cleanout operations (the formulations & mixing of solids free spacers, hi-vis spacers & surfactant spacers etc) & completion operations (Brine & Packer Fluids and Gravel Pack Operations. Also worked as the understudy for Project Engineer position while on days off.

title: C++/Java Developer
description: - Designing and coding all aspects of the software development process, including the front-end user interface for visual appeal and intuitive usability (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, ColdFusion, JSP), back-end development to meet business objectives while maintaining efficient code performance (Java, C++), system administration scripts for automating build/deployment/administration processes (.sh, .bat, Ant, Make), and database development for mapping and persistence (various Object-Relational Mapping frameworks, Oracle PL/SQL) - Programming business logic into a back-end decision engine (C++, distributed CORBA architecture); Decision engine functionality includes interfacing data from major credit bureaus, interpreting a proprietary scripting language for product configuration, performing credit risk analysis, configuring loan application decisioning criteria, and loan application scoring and grading - Providing production-level support and fixes for system issues such as crashes or bugs - Developing interface integration (Web Services, XML-based transactions, and TCP/IP transactions) between the company's system and partner systems - Designing and implementing the low-level details of high-level business goals; Translating general business requirements into software and architecture requirements Technologies used: Java, C++, PL/SQL, ColdFusion, Apache Struts, Hibernate, Persistence, EJB, JSP, CORBA, omniORB, XSLT, XML, Apache Ant, HTML, JavaScript, jQuery, Unix shell scripting, Windows batch scripting, GNU Make, Oracle RDBMS, Eclipse, Linux, Solaris, AIX, Windows Server 2008, some minor C#/VB.NET

title: Intern Software Engineer
description: - Provided proprietary software tools to support over 300 engineers on the Lockheed Martin "ERAM" program, contracted by the FAA for $2.15 billion; Functionality of the tools included streamlining usage of third-party requirements management tools such as ARTiSAN® and DOORS®, data manipulation and integration, and automation of tasks and processes - Held full development responsibility including software design, programming, testing, documentation, end user distribution, and troubleshooting/maintenance. This was a privilege and a challenge, especially considering the number of engineers who are using my tools for their work - Combined all the developed tools into one user interface with the focus of simple, intuitive navigation by creating a systems design template which contains all of the tools as well as descriptive text and visual guides which explain the features of each tool - Improved the working efficiency of engineers by significantly shortening lengthy and tedious stages common in defense contracting product delivery, and enforced customer specifications as well as organizational standards necessary in large-scale projects; Followed up with ex co-workers still on the program and found that the users are happily and effectively using the developed tools - Loaned out to different software engineering departments through positive recognition and reviews of my work, and held multiple project responsibilities through good multitasking Technologies used: .NET (C#, VB.NET), C++, VB6, HTML, JavaScript, XML, Windows desktop application development, UML, SysML, DOORS, ARTiSAN, Visual Studio, VBA ** About the program: ERAM is replacing the previous "HOST" air traffic control program nationwide. With ERAM, air traffic controllers will be able to track 1,900 aircraft at a time, instead of the previous 1,100 from HOST. ERAM is the first major process in unifying all aspects of air traffic control in North America and the U.K. through the FAA's NextGen system.**

title: Sr. Software Engineer
description: Currently, I'm on a project as a Java PKI developer on an agile development program providing development support for Type 1 PKI key establishment. My development activities include using a combination of Java products (J2SE, J2EE, Spring, Hibernate), CM and build management tools (IBM Rational, Jazz, Maven), XML technologies (WSDL, SOAP, JAXB), database software (Oracle, MongoDB), in a virtualized environment using both Windows and Linux (Red Hat) platforms. Additionally, I also provide integration and build management support using Nexus and Jenkins. I worked as J2EE developer on a modernization effort of analyzing cryptographic software coded in PL/I and translating them over into Java. I performed requirements gathering, system design, integration testing, and conduct team peer reviews in addition to coding duties. I served as a cloud analytic developer on a project that specializes in trending patterns. The analytics are implemented analytics using Hadoop MapReduce and I created custom data visualization web applications using ExtJS and RESTful web services. At times, I present the analytics at quarterly technical fests. Outside of analytic development, I develop components for the project's common API which would help promote code reuse for the other analytic projects. I worked on a mission visualization system that is deployed on a widget framework. I coordinated the development, integration and documentation on a variety of efforts including creating metrics reporting, temporal, and geolocation visualizations in ExtJs and developing backend resource servers using J2EE technologies. I also implemented visualization prototypes that could have the potential to released in later spin cycles. Outside of my development duties, I (at times) served as the operational coordinator where I handle any client/customer needs related to the system.

I also work with the FIRST Lego League where I mentor robotics teams and I help judge at the state and world competitions.

title: Reservations Manager
description: Overseeing all aspects of the reservations department with responsibility for managing a staff of 4 persons. As well as responsibility for the Front Office Team of approximately 20 persons in the absence of the Front Office Manager. Upon assuming this position, our average occupancy increased through innovative marketing techniques. Duties include but are not limited to the following:  Managing rooms’ inventory.  Preparing forecasts, monthly and annual performance reports and analyses.  Marketing – attending tradeshows, sales trips and conducting site inspections. One of the hotel's representative annually at the CHTA Market place.  Contracts negotiation.  Recruitment and training.  Duty Manager Role. This includes handling all departmental and guest related matters.

title: Office Manager
description: • Acted as primary point of contact for North America office in a multinational defense company; • Led office as Safety, Health and Environment coordinator to meet and exceed company-wide standards; • Implemented and managed new credit card program in business unit; • Prepared expense reports and helped business unit transition to NetSuite online expense reporting; • Arranged all travel for several executives; planned events and meetings with attendees connecting via teleconference and video; • Worked with business units and customs broker to prepare and track communications with the US Department of State DDTC; • Managed office: responsibilities included scheduling, budgeting, accounts payable, interacting with customers and suppliers; and • Became primary DC office resource for resolving IT issues due to company downsizing.

title: Program Coordinator
description: • Supervise health and wellness staff of 12-15 employees. • Create promotional flyers and posters for group exercise classes and events offered by the Health and Wellness Department. • Manage all social media outlets pertaining to the Wilson Gray YMCA. Assist members in developing attainable fitness goals and how to reach them. • Create monthly fitness challenges to keep members engaged in physical fitness. • Supervise the HIP & FIT afterschool program. summary: Lindsey is a three year member of the Talent Acquisition group at Battelle Memorial Institute in Columbus, Ohio. Battelle is the world’s largest nonprofit research and development organization, generating over $4B in revenue annually in global R&D. In her role at Battelle, Lindsey is responsible for defining new recruiting processes and initiatives while supporting National Security, Energy, Health & Environment, Lab Operations as well as exclusively staffing Chemical Demilitarization sites in Pueblo, CO and Richmond, KY. Lindsey is also responsible for our Military Recruiting Strategy and Military Community Outreach Program. Prior to joining Battelle, Lindsey worked for Mission Essential; a government contractor headquartered in Columbus, Ohio. For over a decade Mission Essential has served customers at the strategic and tactical levels, providing operational solutions to the U.S. Department of Defense, State, and Homeland Security; the Intelligence Community; friendly foreign government; and multinational corporations. Lindsey specialized in performing all complex elements of a variety of professional and administrative recruiting functions in support of identifying, interviewing, evaluating, and selecting qualified, government cleared professionals (ranging from Interim Secret to TS/SCI full scope poly) to effectively meet multiple requirements in support of military rotation exercises and Department of Defense government contracts CONUS and OCONUS. Lindsey is currently working with the U.S. Special Operations Command to develop a Fellowship Program for wounded Special Forces Veterans and is also engaged in planning and operating a quarterly Jobs for Veterans Workshop. Lindsey has over 6 years of diverse HR experience as well as government contracting/ recruiting experience and has a Bachelor’s degree in Sociology from The Ohio State University.

title: Recruiting Specialist, National Security
description: Battelle is the world’s largest nonprofit independent research and development organization, providing innovative solutions to the world’s most pressing needs through its four global businesses: Laboratory Management, National Security, Energy Technology, and Health and Life Sciences. It advances scientific discovery and application by conducting $5.2 billion in global R&D annually through contract research, laboratory management and technology commercialization. Headquartered in Columbus, Ohio, Battelle oversees 20,400 employees in more than 130 cities worldwide, including seven national laboratories that Battelle manages or co-manages for the U.S. Department of Energy and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and two international laboratories—a nuclear energy lab in the United Kingdom and a renewable energy lab in Malaysia.

summary: Lindsey is a three year member of the Talent Acquisition group at Battelle Memorial Institute in Columbus, Ohio. Battelle is the world’s largest nonprofit research and development organization, generating over $4B in revenue annually in global R&D. In her role at Battelle, Lindsey is responsible for defining new recruiting processes and initiatives while supporting National Security, Energy, Health & Environment, Lab Operations as well as exclusively staffing Chemical Demilitarization sites in Pueblo, CO and Richmond, KY. Lindsey is also responsible for our Military Recruiting Strategy and Military Community Outreach Program. Prior to joining Battelle, Lindsey worked for Mission Essential; a government contractor headquartered in Columbus, Ohio. For over a decade Mission Essential has served customers at the strategic and tactical levels, providing operational solutions to the U.S. Department of Defense, State, and Homeland Security; the Intelligence Community; friendly foreign government; and multinational corporations. Lindsey specialized in performing all complex elements of a variety of professional and administrative recruiting functions in support of identifying, interviewing, evaluating, and selecting qualified, government cleared professionals (ranging from Interim Secret to TS/SCI full scope poly) to effectively meet multiple requirements in support of military rotation exercises and Department of Defense government contracts CONUS and OCONUS. Lindsey is currently working with the U.S. Special Operations Command to develop a Fellowship Program for wounded Special Forces Veterans and is also engaged in planning and operating a quarterly Jobs for Veterans Workshop. Lindsey has over 6 years of diverse HR experience as well as government contracting/ recruiting experience and has a Bachelor’s degree in Sociology from The Ohio State University.

title: Imagery and Tracking Intelligence Analyst
description: Intelligence and Imagery Analyst. Duties include monitoring, assessing, and presenting strategic and tactical intelligence to senior leadership and inquiring customers. Experienced live imagery analyst providing ground forces with accurate and timely information through secure satellite and tactical military communications. Daily analysis of live and forensic data associated with threat assessment and security functions regarding military, political, and social issues influencing relations in the Middle East. Responsible for training and supervising new team members and insuring operational security measures are maintained. Tracking and Imagery Intelligence Analyst. Live review of GMTI movement around various parts of Iraq. Cooperative Intelligence analysis with HUMINT, SIGINT, MASINT and All Source personnel to give chain of command overall picture of mission progression. Provided training to new personnel on mission requirements, mock deployed missions and RFI’s. Conducted post mission analysis of operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. Assisted SSO in securing all classified documentation and systems in the Intelligence Cell. Monitored all personnel as a security supervisor for the Intelligence Training Center of Operations (ITCO) and G2 sections.
